comments.commentBody:
I like Joe Biden and he's a good political operative. But he's a bit of a motor mouth too and that's very DANGEROUS in an American President.

Think back to the last president of Iran who was another motor mouth? At least Iran wasn't the most powerful nation on earth.

The American President is, in some ways, the President of the world. That required a huge amount of caution and humbleness.

For getting to 270 electoral votes, Sanders isn't that candidate either.

Who do we have besides Hillary? Nobody!

Bernie Sanders nailed it - the Republicans didn't win in 2014, the Democrats lost. And thanks to the national party's ineptitude, it could happen again in 2016. Few as they are compared with the Republicans, all the Democratic candidates running for the nomination have much more to offer. No party leadership in its right mind would keep these candidates under wraps while the Republican circus gets all the media limelight. Of course it's all to protect Hillary Clinton.

If Mrs. Clinton can prevail after an extended series of debates, she will deserve it and be a stronger candidate in the general election. It does no favors to her, her party or the electorate to tilt the nomination her way. And after seeing the speeches at the DNC, I increasingly fear that she is less equipped to inspire and attract waverers or stay-at-homes than either Bernie Sanders or Martin O'Malley - especially if the GOP candidate were Donald Trump the Pied Piper, who has increasing shown the power of words and their delivery, whether they are inflammatory or just plain nonsense.

The kindest description of the DNC's decision to delay and limit candidate debates is malpractice.

Actually quite a few doctors are in favor of a better health care system than we have now.

Disclosure : two of my children are practicing MDs.
I'll second that, my personal Dr. wants single payer.

Techies have also done well within the current system. (Disclosure - I am a former math instructor from University of California Berkeley and founder of a Silicon Valley software firm.)

People who have done well in any system are unlikely to criticize the system. Few Army generals want to reduce the military budget, and few American doctors agitate for universal government paid health care.

Also, as another commenter points out, tech types are comfortable with material they can control, and avoid messier subjects. Studies of toleration of frustration by techies and marketers discussed by Professor Ackoff of the University of Pennsylvania show that techies tolerate frustration poorly.

Yet we need techies to study problems and find solutions. As the father of quality management, Edwards Deming, used to say, the statisticians must save the world. That means the techies and the talented should get the resources, and inheritance over $1 million should be ended. The money should be used to give every American child a scholarship.

To see other good ideas go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min 9 sec). Then send a buck to Bernie and invite me to speak to your group. Thanks.
Thanks for the reply.  I believe you do know what "progressive" means, and I'm glad.  I don't think that about the people who, like Prof. Krugman, use it as a substitute for "liberal".

Apparently many don't care if their candidate has integrity, otherwise why would Hillary have the backing of 70 % of Democrat voters. And why did Obama get reelected when his first term made it crystal clear that he lacked integrity, "you can keep your insurance plan. Period."

@Al R.: Yes, there are many who don't care. But I'll tell you this, if the DNC continues on this path it is going to be hoisted on it's own petard. It's just a matter of time. There are enough people who are fed up, not only with Hillary but with the machinations of the DNC and those fed-up voices are growing. The DNC's fixation on the "inevitability" of Hillary Clinton's nomination just adds more fuel to the fire.

If she does have "the backing of 70% of democrat voters" then that doesn't reflect well on the electorate, does it? But I'm not a poll watcher (that's Hillary's forte.)

For Hillary's fan base, fantasy and "the will to believe" will always trump facts and inconvenient truths.

Bernie or no Bernie, Hillary will not be getting this vote. Period.

The fundamental reason Hillary is ultimately unelectable is that people don't want a liar and a cheat. That's why her ratings are plummeting and she's dropping in the polls. Most people see through the script and the pretense (the lame response to the email server controversy is but one example.) Most importantly, she lacks that vital winning characteristic - camera appeal. Despite all the bluster, she's uncomfortable and it shows. It's what cost Richard Nixon the election in 1960.

During the financial crisis, trillions evaporated from 401 K's that were the prime source of retirement funds for a majority of Americans. You can thank Bill for that as it was under Bill Clinton's watch that we got deregulation of the financial industry; a seismic change that led the country directly to the brink of an economic catastrophe. That's Bill Clinton's legacy and Hillary is inextricably tied to that legacy. And no, Hillary doesn't get points for staying with him. Not in my book.

People want their candidates to have integrity. They want to be inspired. Hillary, hard as she tries, simply can't produce because she's not in possession of those qualities With Hillary, it's not "What you see is what you get." Rather, what you see is contrived and evasive, like the rehearsed identification with working class/middle class Americans or the awkward responses to the plight of African Americans.

...because, when it comes to the Clintons, it's all cigar smoke and mirrors.

You can't seriously say you support Democrats while saying you might vote for Trump because he will "destroy the political structure as we know it." Two words every voter needs to remember - Supreme Court. Judge Judy, anyone?

I think of Trump as I thought of Reagan.  Ronnie didn't destroy the political structure but rather recast it into an even more diabolical apparatus.  If Trump were to prevail I would expect him to be as sly and canny as Reagan and both Bushes.  You'd be nuts to vote for Trump out of disgust.  He'd take it to a new level.

As Bob Dylan says in his Albert Hall Concert, 'I don't believe you.'  I doubt you are for Bernie, and if you really are, then you're a complete idiot if you think that Trump will be concerned with anything other than how to capitalize his involvement in electoral politics to compensate himself in his eyes for his risk and 'sacrifice.'

I've been behind Bernie since Day One. At the time I would have readily changed my stance and supported Hillary if she won the primary in a fair and open manner. However, given the way Hillary is handling this entire server issue and now learning that Wasserman-Schultz, a known Clinton backer, has a hand in tweaking the debates and primary process makes be think twice. Like many other people, whether they be Democrats, Republicans, Independents, I am sick of the political machines. I could actually see myself voting for Trump. Not because I believe in him or what he says, but because he would destroy the political structure as we know it. This has the potential to be an incredible election year. I do hope the Democrats don't blow it.

Dan: I like those lists. I think you should have included the Antarctic Sea (but it's debatable) and called the Sea of Love #8 (of the Seven Seas, naturally). That must be the sea one wishes to drown in, if required to drown in a sea.

The Persian Gulf is a perfectly good "sea", especially back then.

Capitalism is only for the 1%.  Capitalism only values the work that the 1% does.  The other 99% of workers are the ones who are actually doing the valuable work:  nurses, firefighters, police, plumbers, carpenters, restaurant workers, hotel workers, even the garbage collectors.  And these are the people that are losing out to capitalism.  (Sorry I know I am forgetting a lot of valuable occupations...........there is not enough room to cover them all.)  I get sooooooo tired of hearing people say that the 1% earn their dollars as if the rest of us somehow don't.

Barack had his red states - blue states speech. He had his race speech. Reagan said "tear down this wall" and talked about "morning in America". W. said "mission accomplished". FDR told us that there is "nothing to fear but fear itself". Carter encouraged us to wear sweaters in the living room in the winter time.

Politicians have an opportunity and even an obligation to paint in broad strokes for the citizenry catch phrases that we and, later, history can reflect on.

Bernie needs to tell us what socialism means to him. How does it differ from communism? How can socialism co-exist with capitalism, even our current right-biased glorified capitalism?

On one hand, it may not help Bernie win this cycle, but on the other he does currently share with the Donald an apparent 20% plateau of the electorate, so he needs to compel a larger group, and he might as well proudly explain his -isms.

By the way, either we should be wearing sweaters in the living room in the winter, or it doesn't matter any more. Thanks Jimmy for trying.

Republicans are fighting against the "obvious" candidate the establishment is shoving down our throats. The Party knows this but as yet seems unwilling to listen to its members. If it continues on this path the 2016 vote will resemble the McCain and Dole campaigns. Millions of Republican voters will stay home or just vote the lower part of the ballot.

The party establishments of both the Dems and Repubs have chosen their candidates --- Clinton and Bush --- and that's the choice they'll offer us in November 2016.  Which makes me sad.  Because that will mean the status quo wins yet again.  It really is time for a dramatic change in the electoral system of the USA so that we can get responsible governance.  My best case scenario would have underdogs like Sanders and O'Malley and Webb have a large effect on the eventual outcome.  Is it likely?  No.  But I still hope for it.
I will write in Bernie Sanders name if he is not on the ballot in 2016.

TK.
I understand your disappointment in Mrs. Clinton. ( Go Bernie! )
However, to not cast a vote for a Democratic President is a vote for the Republican Party. Period!
With two possible SCOTUS appointments to be made it is imperative that they be of a Liberal/Progressive persuasion.
The lesser of two evils is still LESS evil!!!
Please, Get. Out. and Vote!!!

Those of us who won't vote for Hillary under any circumstances need to be prepared to write "Bernie Sanders" on our ballot in the next election. It may well be that doing so will ensure the election of a Republican.... but it will also be a big enough vote that the Democrat establishment will never again force an "inevitable" candidate down our throats.
Bernie for President!

As a progressive-leaning Independent,  I won't vote Republican, based on those candidates and their positions (or lack thereof). That being said, I will not vote for Hillary Clinton under any circumstance. Listen-up, DNC. I will not rally 'round Hillary, so please stop force-feeding her down our throats. If you do, you lose my vote, as I will not participate in your pre-ordained anointment. There's at least one other candidate from the Democratic Party, and try as you may, he's your best bet (Bernie Sanders).
Why not go all-in and vote for the Republican candidate? I know – why bother; your abstention does exactly that.
If you don't vote, whoever did the buying will get what they paid for.

If Hillary is nominated, I will vote. I will write "Bernie Sanders" on my ballot.
The Democrat Party needs to become truly democratic.... not yield to some "inevitable" and "entitled" establishment candidate.
Hillary hasn't been able to deal with the e-mail controversy.... and folks want her in the White House to deal with ISIS and other complicated problems?
Hillary can't win. In part because people like me are willing to see Trump in the White house if the Democra Party tries to ram Hillary down our throats. 4 years of Trump will ensure Democrat victories for decades to come.
Bernie in '16!
If Clinton is nominated, I will not vote.  She is bought and paid for.  Unfortunately, she does not represent me.

The last time a political party scheduled only 6 debates was in 1980, when the GOP was scared that the "radical fringe" ultra-conservative insurgent Ronald Reagan would beat the "establishment" candidates GHW Bush and Bob Dole. The RNC wanted to protect their chosen candidates just like Wasserman Schultz does. And look how that turned out!

I think it may be unprecedented that the national party is prohibiting candidates from participating in any but the party-sanctioned debates.  This is certainly deliberate rigging by Wasserman-Schultz - it prevents the other candidates from debating without Hillary.  I also like the Sanders idea of taking opportunities to debate republicans.  Shame on the DNC.

Your examples are somewhat outdated, all from the 1960's and 1970's, O'Malley is speaking of modern times where the democratic party usually supports debates amongst their presidential candidates. Sometimes less is not more.

Although I am sympathetic to O'Malley's gripe about the limitations on debates, he is plainly wrong when he says that it is unprecedented. Debates, until recently, were the exception, not the norm, in electoral politics. Before the Kennedy-Nixon debate, one would have to go before the television and radio eras to find any debates whatsoever. After the Kennedy Nixon debates of 1960, there were no debates until 1976. IN 1968, there was only one Democratic debate in the primary season: It was RFK v. Mc Carthy (The pro Vietnam war contingent had already rigged the convention in their favor and they did not need to win any primaries. By Nov 67, 40 percent of the delegates to the 68 dem convention had already been chosen and they were all pro war hacks. The anti war contingent, RFK and Eugene did not have a chance. Hence the battle in the streets.)
Speaking of rigging: It is a bit rigged in HIllary's favor but it is nothing like the rigging that used to transpire.
Sanders is right on the money: The low turnout is killing democrats. Poor people, who should be voting democratic, are staying at home because their issues are not being articulated.

Perhaps the first step in shaking the sterile torpor of the Democratic party is sprucing up the venue a touch. I understand that the Dems don't share the same super-PAC bucks that the GOP enjoys but, for Bernie's sake, they should at least upgrade that stair railing before one of the candidates topples off-stage like Bob Dole in the '96 election.
If their duct-tape laden scaffold is a metaphor for their political platform's condition, we're not in for a good four years--or more.

Dylan111-- i agree, being a Dem, that it is imperative that women have a strong, strong voice in our party in 2016. But let's not make Hillary's appeal to women the most important facet of the election, either. We have so many other important issues, from wage inequality for so many, not just women, and the immigration issue, and Iran, just to name a few. Let's not take our eye off the ball that the Democratic Party is not just the old white man's party, like the GOP, but is a diverse group representing many constituencies with many needs. And my goodness, it is so important, so very important, that the Dems have the best candidate possible... we now see that it is quite possible that Trump could be the candidate, and he would/will be a huge problem for any Dem candidate, because he speaks simple things that angry people want to hear.

Sorry, but the first woman president should not get to the White House because of who she married, and the first woman president should not have done the indefensible - defending and supporting her husband after he was caught having a sordid affair with an intern just a few years older than their daughter.
No, he did that because Vermont, with one of the lowest murder rates in the US, has the most lax gun laws. Guns don't kill people, people kill people.
But she's not popular in the polls. Given her name recognition, barely breaking 45% is pathetic.

Hillary isn't saying anything, at least not what I want to hear.  Bernie Sanders is.  The unspoken, dirty elephant in the living room is corporate rule, and I think Hillary is just one more of their servants.  I'm sick of her kind of politics.  Her husband was half a democrat.

I did, we have. He supported it because his voter base in rural Vermont, like any rural area are Republican voting hunters. He's even on record, stating the difference between gun usage/crime in cities and gun usage in the country. If anything, it just supports the fact that he listens to his constituency, instead of fishing for votes and begging billionaires for their money.

Bernie speaks truth to power. I, like Bernie, lived through 3 decades of middle class prosperity where parents could afford a home, send their kids to college and not go into bankruptcy with a hospital stay. That ended thirty years ago when Wall Street subsidized Walmart expansion which began the downfall of Main Street USA small business. Then of course Bill Clinton ended traditional banking practices (Glass-Steagall Act) by signing the Gramm-Leach-Bililey Act which gave banks a license to gamble your savings away. Bernie 2016.

Trump is not the problem; he is a diversion to remove attention from the Republican Party's scheme to buy political power with free-flowing cash from the Brothers Koch and cohorts. The SCOTUS has been aiding and abetting the thieving Republicans with a series of in-your-face decisions, the most audacious of which was the selection of George Bush for President by the Scalia mob. Then they unleashed the Kochs on American democracy and the brothers have been shredding it with fanfare.

As long as the middle class in this country keeps looking to the billionaires as "successful" Americans rather than the thieves they are of the fruits of other people's labor, the Republican Party has nothing to fear.

The delegate selection process is nearly identical to that used in 2008. What is rigged is the cap on the limit on the number of debates. There are 6 scheduled for 2016. There were far more in 2008. Moreover, the DNC edict includes the proviso that any candidate who participates in an unsanctioned debate cannot participate in the DNC debates.

That is what is rigged. Challengers want debates; frontrunners do not. In that sense, the process is indeed rigged in favor of the frontrunner.

So far, and once again, the email "scandal" is another Whitewater: there's no there there.

Rather than attack Hillary by focusing on non-existent wrongdoing, try speaking to her actual corporate-supporting policies, the same policies that both Obama and her husband, tools of the Robert Rubin wing of the Democratic Party, support. This would be the wing that helped to overturn the Glass-Steagall Act under Bill Clinton, refused to prosecute a single banker for the destruction of the world economy under Obama and wants to raise interest rates to help bond holders instead of working people.

This is the wing that is supporting recently-ex-Republican Patrick Murphy (and member of the the Republican wing of the Democratic Party) for Florida senator instead of Alan Grayson; the same people that wouldn't support Justin Coussoule when he ran against John Boehner in Ohio in 2010.

And for all people who want to support Hillary because she's a woman, start supporting people for their policies and their records (did someone say Bernie Sanders?) instead of their gender or their color--unless all other things are equal.
Sorry, but that is a cynical assessment not supported by his record in Congress over decades.
